title-group.article-title: Effect of contact area variation on squeal propensity of disc modes

article-meta.aff: Division of Mechanical and Automotive Engineering, Kongju National University, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Jaeyoung Kang, Division of Mechanical and Automotive Engineering, Kongju National University, Cheonan-si, Chungnam, Korea. Email: jkang@kongju.ac.kr

abstract.p: The squeal propensity associated with the contact area variation is studied using the finite element method and the analytical contact and rotating modeling. The disc brake system is modeled as a rotating finite element disc in contact with annular sector-friction material. The squeal propensity is numerically determined with respect to the contact span angle and the radial contact length which define the contact geometry. The results show that the squeal propensity is strongly influenced by the contact area variation. Particularly, the squeal propensity of the transverse doublet mode changes periodically with the variation of the contact span angle. However, the in-plane dominant modes have the decreased squeal tendency as the span angle increases. The variation in the radial contact length is also shown to make contribution to the change in squeal propensity for both the transverse and in-plane modes.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Brake squeal problem is one of the major warranty claims in the automotive industry. Great attention has been paid to this single problem. Many engineers and scientists have studied the brake squeal over the several decades as reviewed in Kinkaid et al.1

Finite element (FE) method has been one popular tool solving the complex eigenvalue analysis for the brake squeal propensity. Nack2,3 proposed the simple contact modeling, where the slip is assumed to be only the circumferential direction of disc rotation. From this linear squeal model, the squeal mechanism based on mode-coupling has been broadly studied. Bajer et al.4,5 introduced the two-dimensional slip, where the radial slip was incorporated into the contact modeling and it turned out to be the frictional damping.

However, it is well known that FE approach has several drawbacks. It requires long time for analyzing the single model configuration. Also, the lack of the mathematical formulation prevents the researchers from seeking the definite squeal mechanisms. For this reason, FE or analytical disc brake models for the various design parameter study have been developed as referred to Chowdhary et al.,6 Huang et al.,7,8 Kang et al.9–11 Recently, Kang12 developed the FE squeal model associated with the analytical formulation of the contact and rotating modeling, where new rotation effects were investigated. This analytical FE method can easily construct the complex contact and geometric modeling. Also, it can save the simulation time by solving many design parameter variations in a single simulation, which is critical in design parameter study.

One of the major design parameters in brake squeal is the contact area configuration. Kang et al.9 investigated the effect of the contact span angle on squeal propensity using the analytical vibration model with the stationary annular plate. It was found that the squeal propensity of the transverse disc doublet modes is strongly influenced by the contact span angle. Nouby et al.13 showed that the squeal propensity can be reduced by changing the contact geometry such as the slot configuration and chamfer shape using ABAQUS. Oberst and Lai14 experimentally showed the changes in the noise occurrence with respect to the slot geometry variation by conducting the brake dynamometer test.

In this article, the contact area function is analytically incorporated into the FE brake model. Accordingly, the complex eigenvalue variation associated with contact area variation can be solved in a single simulation. Unstable vibration modes are to be determined first. Then, their squeal propensity due to contact area variation is investigated. Particularly, the transverse disc doublet modes and the in-plane dominant modes are of concern in this study.

sec.title: Derivation
sec.p:
The disc brake system is modeled as a FE actual disc subject to the pre-normal load (No), as shown in Figure 1. The influence of the pad vibration modes on squeal propensity is not of interest in this study. Therefore, the pad is assumed to be rigid without motion. Pad vibration definitely affects the squeal propensity of the disc modes having the close frequencies with the pad mode.10 In other words, this assumption is good for the specific disc modes with frequencies away from the pad one. The contact area is defined as an annular sector shape, where the inner and outer contact radii (ri and ro), and the contact span angle (θc) are the design parameters. In this study, the non-uniform pressure distribution and wear effect are not accounted for and the contact stiffness (kc) is assumed to be uniformly distributed over the contact area. The reference frame (XYZ) and the local frame (xyz) are defined, as shown in Figure 2, where the local frame rotates along with the constant rotation speed (Ω) of the disc. Figure 1.
Configuration of a rotating FE disc in contact with friction material of annular sector shape. Figure 2.
Reference and rotating coordinate systems.

In the friction-engaged brake system, the displacement vector can be discretized by the assumed modes satisfying the boundary conditions such that (1)u~(x~,t)=u~(x~,t)er+v~(x~,t)eθ+w~(x~,t)ez≅∑n=1 Nd [ {ϕr(n) (x~ )er+ϕψ(n) (x~ )eθ+ϕz(n) (x~ )ez }qn(t) ] where Nd is the truncated number of modes and the position in the undeformed state is denoted by x~=(r,ψ,z) in the local frame (xyz). ϕr(n), ϕψ(n), and ϕz(n) are the nth mode shape functions obtained from the modal analysis. The position vector of the disc in the deformed state, therefore, is given by (2)r~(x~,t)=rer+zez+u~(x~,t)

The corresponding velocity vector can be expressed in the reference frame (XYZ) using the coordinate transformation such that (3)V(x,t)=∂r(x,t)∂t+Ω∂r(x,t)∂θ where the differentiation is conducted with respect to the time and the global coordinates x=(r,θ,z). The overbar •~ will be removed if a variable is expressed in the global coordinates. Also, the velocity vector at the tip of the contact spring is obtained as the reference12 such that (4)Vtip(xc,t)=∂utip(xc,t)∂t where xc represents the contact position vector in the undeformed state and (5)utip(xc,t)=w(xc,t)ez

Therefore, the friction stress over the contact surface can be written in the form of Coulomb’s law of friction with friction coefficient (μ) (6)F(xc,t)=-μpVrel|Vrel| where Vrel is the relative slip velocity between the disc and the tip of the contact spring at the certain contact point (7)Vrel(xc,t)=V(xc,t)-Vtip(xc,t) (8)μ(r,t)=μk+(μs-μk)e-β|Vrel| (9)p=po+kcáu(xc,t),ezñ

Vrel/|Vrel| indicates the direction vector of the friction stress. The contact normal stress p is the sum of the pre-normal stress po and the normal load variation due to the disc vibration kcáu(xc,t),ezñ, where po is the normal stress generated by the uniform distribution of the pre-load No over the contact area. It is noted that the friction coefficient is dependent on the several physical conditions, where μs, μk, and β can be the control parameters fitting the experimental friction curve.15

Using the assumed modes method, the equations of motion can be expressed in the following form such that (10)ddt[∂L∂q·m]-∂L∂qm=∑n=1 NdQmn(qn),m=1,…,Nd (11)L=T-(U+Uc) where qm is the mth modal coordinate, and the kinetic energy T and the contact strain energy Uc are given by (12)T=ρ2×∫Vd(V•V)dV (13)Uc=kc2∫Ac +áu(xc +),ezñ2dA+kc2∫Ac -áu(xc -),ezñ2dA where Vd represents the volume of the disc, and Ac + and Ac - (or xc + and xc -) denote the top and bottom contact surfaces, respectively. The strain energy U of the uncoupled disc is obtained from the modal analysis using the commercial FE software. The generalized force Qmn can be derived from the virtual work done by contact stresses such that (14)δW=∑n=1 NdQmn(qn)·δqm=∫Ac +{(p(xc +)ez+F(xc +))·δu(xc +)-(p(xc +)ez+F(xc +))·δutip(xc +)}dA+∫Ac -{(p(xc -)ez+F(xc -))·δu(xc -)-(p(xc -)ez+F(xc -))·δutip(xc -)}dA

The numerical contact area integration can take the analytical form as (15)∫Ac +(•)dA=∫Ac -(•)dA=∫-θc/2 +θc/2∫ri ro(•)rdrdθ where the contact area is determined by the contact span angle (θc) and the inner and outer radii (ri and ro) which will be the major numerical parameters in this study. In the FE approach, the numerical contact area integration is conducted such that (16)∫-θc/2 +θc/2∫ri ro(•)rdrdθ=∑l=1 Mr∑m=1 Mθ(•)rl·Δrl·Δθm where Mr and Mθ are the number of nodes over the contact area in the r and θ directions, respectively. For a specific contact area, the modal vector of each node over the given contact area is numerically obtained. Figure 3 indicates the set of nodal vectors of the specific mode over the contact surface, as defined in equation (15). These nodal information extracted through the modal analysis is applied to the equations of motion (10). Figure 3.

By linearizing equation (10) at the steady-sliding equilibrium, the linearized equations of motion can be written in the matrix form such that (17)q··+(G+C)q·+(Ksym+Kasym)q=0 where q is the modal vector, G the skew-symmetric gyroscopic matrix, and C the symmetric damping matrix arising from the friction-slope and the radial slip dissipation.5,11 Ksym and Kasym are the symmetric and asymmetric stiffness matrices, respectively. By substituting q=eλta into equation (17), the eigenvalue λ can be obtained in the complex form. Its real parts Re(λ) represent the modal stability of its imaginary parts corresponding to the modal frequencies.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The complex eigenvalue analysis is conducted for the linearized equations of motion (17). In this analysis, the 62 vibration modes including the 10th nodal diameter mode up to 15,000 Hz are used. The system parameters used in the simulation are shown in Table 1. The control parameters of the friction coefficient in equation (8) are chosen for having a negative friction-slope, as shown in Figure 4. For the further analysis, the constant rotation speed is set to be Ω=6rad/s. Figure 4.

From the frequency plot with respect to the contact stiffness variation, several modes are found to be unstable, as illustrated in Figure 5. These modal instabilities arise from the destabilization mechanism such as the mode-coupling and the negative friction-velocity slope. The detailed mechanisms can be referred to Kang et al.11 Figure 5.
Modal stability map; dot indicates the unstable mode with Re(λ)>0, K=kc/kc,nominal×100[ %].

In this analysis, the unstable modes stem from two types of vibration modes: the transverse doublet modes (Figure 6) and the in-plane dominant modes (Figure 7).The transverse modes can be characterized by the number of nodal lines such that mode23,24, mode32,33, and mode41,42 have 5, 6, and 7 nodal lines, respectively. These modes are the doublet modes of which pair has the close frequencies. Of the in-plane dominant modes, mode30,31 and mode34,35 will be called the disc-hat doublet modes because their hat part swings back and forth leading to the in-plane dominant movement of the rotor part. Also, mode 48 is the typical disc torsion mode in which the hat and rotor parts rotate in the twisted manner. Figure 6.
Mode shapes of the unstable transverse doublet modes in Figure 5, (a) mode23,24(5 nodal diameters), (b) mode32,33 (6 nodal diameters), and (c) mode40,41 (7 nodal diameters). Figure 7.
Mode shapes of the unstable in-plane modes in Figure 5, (a) mode30,31 (disc-hat doublet modes), (b) mode34,35 (disc-hat doublet modes), and (c) mode48 (torsion mode).

In order to investigate the influence of the contact area geometry on squeal propensity, the dynamic instability is numerically determined with respect to the contact span angle. Figure 8 demonstrates the squeal propensity of the in-plane modes for the contact span variation. The squeal propensity of mode30,31 (disc-hat mode) and mode48 (torsion mode) are rarely affected by the contact span variation. In contrast, it is shown that the increase of the contact span variation can reduce the squeal propensity in the one of the disc-hat doublet modes (mode34,35). The similar numerical simulation is conducted for the transverse disc doublet modes, as illustrated in Figure 9, where the squeal propensity is strongly influenced by the contact span angle. The detailed analytical approach for the transverse mode of an annular plate can be referred to Kang et al.9 Figures 10 and 11 demonstrate that the contact span dependency on squeal onset changes with respect to the contact stiffness variation. From the results, the squeal propensity of the transverse doublet modes is shown to be strongly dependent on the contact stiffness variation, as opposed to the in-plane dominant modes. Figure 8.

Squeal propensity of the transverse doublet modes with respect to the contact span angle, solid: mode23,24 (5 nodal diameter), thick solid: mode32,33 (6 nodal diameter), and dot: mode40,41 (7 nodal diameter), K = 100%. Figure 10.
Squeal propensity of the in-plane modes with respect to contact stiffness and span angle, (a) mode30,31 (disc-hat doublet modes), (b) mode34,35 (disc-hat doublet modes), and (c) mode48 (torsion mode). Figure 11.
Squeal propensity of the transverse doublet modes with respect to contact stiffness and span angle, (a) mode23,24 (5 nodal diameter), (b) mode32,33 (6 nodal diameter), and (c) mode40,41 (7 nodal diameter).

The radial contact length (ro-ri) is also used to be the design parameter. By changing the outer contact radius with a fixed inner radius, the effect of the radial contact length is investigated as well. Figures 12 and 13 indicate that the squeal propensity of the in-plane and transverse modes varies with respect to the outer radius variation. Particularly, the squeal propensity of mode32,33 (6 nodal diameter), mode 34,35 (disc-hat), and mode40,41 (7 nodal diameter) effectively increases with the increase of the outer contact radius. Figure 12.
Squeal propensity of the in-plane modes with respect to the outer radius, solid: mode30,31 (disc-hat doublet modes), thick solid: mode34,35 (disc-hat modes), and dot: mode48 (torsion mode), K = 100%. Figure 13.
Squeal propensity of the transverse doublet modes with respect to the outer radius, solid: mode23,24 (5 nodal diameter), thick solid: mode32,33 (6 nodal diameter), and dot: mode40,41 (7 nodal diameter), K = 100%.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The FE brake model was developed for parametrizing the contact geometry in the analytical manner. The stability map due to contact stiffness variation provided the clear overview on the modal instability under the certain operating conditions. From the plot, the transverse disc doublet modes were found to be sensitive in the dynamic instability. Also, several in-plane dominant modes such as the disc-hat modes and the torsion mode are prone to be unstable. The squeal propensity due to the contact area variation has been investigated for these instability-sensitive modes.

The contact span angle was the influencing factor on squeal induced by the transverse doublet modes. For the transverse doublet mode, the increase in the contact span angle produced the certain periodic pattern in squeal propensity. In contrast, it slightly decreased the squeal tendency of the in-plane dominant modes. The radial contact length was also the important parameter in squeal occurrence. As it increased, in general, the squeal propensity was increased in both the transverse and in-plane modes. However, the squeal propensity of one transverse doublet mode was decreased above the certain value of the outer contact radius.

In conclusion, the contact area strongly influences on the squeal generation. Obviously, the absolute area of contact is not proportional to the squeal propensity, but the pattern of squeal propensity is associated with the contact area variation. This analytical FE brake model will provide the efficient and accurate tool for estimating the pattern of squeal propensity associated with the contact geometry such as the chamfer shape and slot configuration of the brake pad.
